Award.AwardTitle: The Design Cognition of Professional Engineers and How They Differ from Students

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to characterize the design cognition (design thinking) of professional engineering designers and to compare their design cognition with that of student engineers designing. Previous NSF-funded projects that involved studying engineers designing have primarily focused on studying students designing. There is a paucity of research on studying professional engineers designing. The science of engineering design requires empirical results not just from students but also from professionals. The empirical research method used to gain access to engineers design cognition is protocol analysis. This project uses a design-based ontological coding scheme to derive information from protocol studies of professional engineers designing. This coding scheme provides the foundation for describing the design cognition of designers and converts the qualitative data in a video of a designer into quantitative data from which statistical models of design behavior can be generated. These models characterize the design cognition of the designers. They are then used to compare the design cognition of professional engineers with that of students, whose design cognition was characterized in a previous NSF-funded study. Deliverable include an archive of protocol videos, a set of protocol transcripts, and a set of research methodologies as well as the statistical models.

If successful, this research will characterize the design behavior of professional engineers. This will then be compared with the behavior predicted by formal models of designing. The results of this research are intended to provide the basis for determining similarities and differences between the design behavior of professional engineers and undergraduate engineers. The results will be disseminated to allow for improvement in design education to bring students to closer to professional engineers during their undergraduate and graduate design education. The results are intended to lay the foundation for the generation of design support tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Knowing how engineers design allows us potentially to improve their design process and to affect the teaching of design to engineering students. The development of a scientific foundation for the understanding of engineering design requires empirical data from engineers designing. The majority of empirical studies of engineers designing have been focused on students, largely because of their ready availability and in the difficulty of attracting a large enough cohort of professional designers. This project studied professional engineers designing using a method that elicits data from their design conversations and allows the development of quantitative models. This method is based on an ontological description of designs and designing that makes its results commensurable with those from other empirical studies.

The results of comparing professional engineers with students has shown some important unexpected commonalities as well as some unexpected differences. These include different rates of expenditure of cognitive effort on different aspect of designing. The rate of expenditure of cognitive effort on the solution, in particular, by professionals was found to be different to that of students. Another significant difference between professional and students is in the design patterns that can be found in their design sessions. Design patterns are regularities in behavior that are used over and over again. Professional designers have developed patterns based on experience that are not found in student design sessions. These patterns cover more activity for professional designers.

The effect of this new knowledge is to allow the testing of design theories and the assessment of student progress towards professional engineering design.

The method used in this project is now being used in other research projects to determine and describe design behavior. The focus on design is significant because designing is one of the drivers of economic and social wealth and is a foundation for US international competitiveness.
